However, these shifts are not strictly environmental, but cultural, historical, and perennial. Andrew Stuhl's Unfreezing the Arctic: Sci- ence, Colonialism and the Transformation of Inuit Lands disambigu- ates our perceptions of the North American Arctic, illuminating several shifts in the history of the Far North. Stuhl challenges the assumption he calls the ‘New North’, which is that the Arctic is for the ﬁrst time changing, in contrast to the ‘Old North's’ immuta- bility. Even as North American scientists, in theory, have come to understand it scientiﬁcally, our conceptions of the Arctic have been bound up in largely monolithic notions, perpetuated by media culture's desperate portrayal of the melting Arctic. Stuhl sets out, with great success, to show how scientiﬁc visions of the Arctic have been constituted and constructed by British explorers, Amer- ican whalers, Canadian scientists, national governments, and Inuit peoples. More importantly, he shows how colonial strategies and techniques for control, as well as indigenous resistance in response, have been shaped by these speciﬁc visions of nature. Stuhl's argument hinges upon how scientiﬁc representations of the Arctic inﬂuenced colonial policies. Although representations of the Far North shifted with ‘southerners’’ values over a century, several things, he argues, have remained the same. First, Inuit have always been resilient, despite a multitude of ‘displacements’: from fur trading to government-mandated reindeer herding; from subsistence to fossil fuel-based market economies; from northern experts to unskilled wards of the state to human rights activists. Secondly, the southern response e both in the United States and Canada e to the Arctic has always been integrally tied to percep- tions of Arctic nature. Stuhl illustrates this by examining ﬁve shifts in scientiﬁc visions of Arctic nature. Beginning in the late nine- teenth century, he identiﬁes the perception of the ‘dangerous’ Arctic in shaping colonial experience during the waning days of the British fur trade. The second chapter focuses on the portrayal of the Arctic as ‘threatened’ and in need of scientiﬁc management. In his most persuasive chapter, focusing on the representation of the Arctic as ‘wild’, which prompted moves to cultivate reindeer herding as a viable option for taming both the land and Inuit living in the Western Arctic, Stuhl demonstrates an important point: the transnational nature of these political decisions. Both the United States and Canada had high stakes in the Western Arctic; the intro- duction of reindeer was a policy that showed, in particular, these place-speciﬁc relationships and conceptualizations, regardless of national boundaries. In the fourth chapter, Stuhl analyzes an Arctic mobilized for wartime, particularly the deployment of permafrost science to address concerns about development. Finally, Stuhl arrives at the Arctic that twenty-ﬁrst-century North Americans are perhaps most familiar with: the Arctic as ‘disturbed.’ This disturbance, he makes clear, extends beyond environmental disturbance; it encap- sulates the disturbances to indigenous communities in the Western Arctic whose interests have been repeatedly cast aside to prioritize the visions and expectations of southern policy-makers. Ultimately, Stuhl's historical analysis offers an important repre- sentation of the Arctic that we continually forget: peopled. Stuhl's goal is to remind scholars and the public, through his accessible writing, that the Arctic is not without history, but demanding of closer historical investigation. Stuhl, who spent extended periods of time in the Western Arctic, makes it clear that current rhetoric around climate change is dismissive of the most important stake- holders in transformations to Arctic lands. Inuit voices have most frequently been drowned out by scientists, policy makers, and busi- nessmen, until scientists and indigenous activists, motivated by environmentalism and humanism, united in the 1970s. While an important message in light of the popularity of, as Stuhl points out, the polar bear as poster child for climate change, Stuhl's book is not only an excellent piece of activist history, but an impor- tant contribution to two historical disciplines. Stuhl's book successfully adopts the critical lens of the historian of science towards the scientiﬁc enterprise while examining ques- tions central to the discipline of environmental history: how are landscapes transformed and broadly, envisioned, over time? More- over, how has science, speciﬁcally, been complicit in the perpetua- tion of various Arctic visions, which carried great authority in making political decisions about that place? In this way, he subverts one of the historian of science's primary critiques of environmental history: the usage of scientiﬁc data as historical evidence. However, he also breaks free from a traditional internalist bent to the history of science, engaging with broader trends in changing twentieth- century science e natural history, ecology, soil science, environ- mental science, and larger cultural and political changes. He shows not only how there has been an ecology of Arctic visions that dismantle, in their very existence, the problematic stories of the ‘Old’ and ‘New North’, but also that an ecological spectrum of inter- connected and socially constructed sciences were involved in the colonial and postcolonial processes that established those many Arctic visions. In addition, he highlights the ecology of different communities of scientists, commercial enterprises, policy-makers, and Inuit, all stakeholders in the Arctic, and all with varying interests and ideas about the Arctic future. These invested parties were perpetuators of different visions over the course of the twentieth century. They remind us that the Arctic environment is not the only thing at stake, but also indigenous communities whose agency has been consis- tently overlooked by louder voices. Though it would be easy to accuse Stuhl of unfounded optimism regarding climate change and the Arctic, he does offer a framework for a more collaborative approach to determining environmental policy. Lines in the Ice: Exploring the Roof of the World, Philip J. Hat- ﬁeld. The British Library, London (2016). 224 pages, £25 hardcover. The Arctic has a particularly powerful place in the popular imag- ination and is often simplistically represented as ‘an unspoilt, un- peopled space of spectacular ice formations’ (p. 14). Lines in the Ice provides an effective challenge to this passive Arctic depiction and explores the long, complex, and at times unsavoury history of European exploration in this northernmost region. Using collec- tions held at the British Library as its starting point, this substantial text is to be commended strongly for both its wide temporal scope as well as the breadth of archival materials upon which it draws. Seeking to give a nuanced cultural history of exploration in the Po- lar North, author and curator Philip Hatﬁeld skilfully brings together maps, images, artefacts, and letters from European, Amer- ican, and indigenous communities and presents them in an attrac- tive, intriguing, and thoroughly readable fashion. The text also contributes to understandings of the connections between historic voyages of discovery and the modern-day challenges shaping hu- man interaction with the Arctic regions. The ﬁrst broad chapter concerns ‘The Draw of the Arctic’ and ex- amines the origins of European interest in the Polar regions during the fourteenth, ﬁfteenth, and sixteenth centuries. Unpacking the disparate, and yet often overlapping, reasons behind European Arctic exploration, Hatﬁeld explores the social, economic, and (geo)political factors that have driven explorers to risk their lives and venture forth into this often unforgiving region. Tracing the journeys of merchants, military men, and privateers as they voyaged ever further in to the Arctic, the text's series of short vi- gnettes give just enough detail to encourage the reader to investi- gate further these key episodes in the history of the region. One of the text's particular strengths in this chapter is the presentation of relics from the pivotal points of encounter between indigenous and non-indigenous peoples in the High North. Hatﬁeld skilfully juxtaposes a fascinating collection of artwork and cultural products from the indigenous populations of Canada, Greenland, and North- ern Russia, with the maps, drawings, and other depictions of the Arctic that were created by European explorers during their travels. Such a structure puts focus on the interplay and interconnections between these two supposedly disparate groups in a manner akin to resurgent attempts in recent academic literature. The second chapter centres on the nineteenth century and draws attention to renewed British interest in the Arctic following the lengthy hiatus of the Napoleonic Wars that had inevitably reshaped the priorities of European countries. Hatﬁeld explores the means by which Britain in particular, now armed with a surplus of both men and seafaring vessels, transitioned from ‘being a nation under pressure to the dominant colonial power of the age’ (p. 92). Also of interest here are the implications resulting from the new techno-scientiﬁc sensibility that was sweeping its way through Britain and its empire. Despite on occasion being nothing more than thinly veiled attempts to justify future Arctic expeditions, experimentation became an essential element of any journey north, and Hatﬁeld presents the plethora of intriguing scientiﬁc materials that were published upon the return to European shores by the likes of William Edward Parry, Joseph Hooker, and William Scoresby. This period also saw a blossoming of literary depictions of the Arctic, perhaps the most famous of which was Shelley's depiction in Frankenstein (1818)da cautionary tale of humanity overreaching its capabilities and suffering the disastrous conse- quences. Hatﬁeld shows how the Arctic was to live up to this peril- ous trope, detailing the tragic fates of the crews of HMS Terror and HMS Erebus. He presents artefacts from the substantial cultural boom which developed around the disaster; highlights include an illustration of Charles Dickens acting in the Wilkie Collins play The Frozen Deep (1856), and a map with a section drawn by Lady Franklin, striving desperately to rally support for a search-and- rescue expedition. Such items, Hatﬁeld implies, strongly inﬂuenced the future narrative surrounding polar exploration. It will be inter- esting to see if and how the recent discoveries of both of Franklin's ships will reinvigorate these ideas. The ﬁnal chapter guides the reader through the intricate com- plexities of the Arctic's place during the Cold War and leads on to the modern-day challenges facing this contested boreal space. The ways in which militant international relations between the world's superpowers were to shape both the physical and imagined landscape of the Arctic are discussed, but, importantly, so too are the more-nuanced ways power has been exerted over the region, for example through methods of mapping and the naming of topo- graphical or marine features. Hatﬁeld does well to highlight the role that European, Russian, and North-American exploratory activ- ity has played in overwriting ‘a landscape rich in the language and knowledge of another, indigenous culture’ (p. 224) and points to moves to combat this erasure via a resurgent interest in Inuit cul- tural products that, until recently, have been overlooked, hidden, or simply ignored. Finally, the role of technology in the Arctic is again discussed. In addition to pointing to the more well-known (or at least better-publicised) innovations involved in the moni- toring of global climate change, Hatﬁeld also discusses how tech- nology is helping indigenous communities to articulate the importance of the Arctic landscape in their daily lives, and hence garner support for increased political agency and the preservation of their threatened cultural heritage. This book raises some important questions that are still being worked out in the ﬁeld of Atlantic slavery. How do we narrate the history of unfreedom and coerced labor in all of its expansiveness without minimizing the pervasiveness and horror of race-based slavery? Can we ever completely extricate the enslaving of human beings from considerations of prejudice and race (or proto-racism)? Throughout, slavery for Guasco was not a ﬁrm and stable institu- tion. It was malleable, ﬂuid, and rarely race-based until the mid- seventeenth century. As such, this book enters into the old fray over when and where racialized slavery began. Rather than simply taking sides, Guasco is determined to narrate cultural mentalities and wider developments as they occurred in their contexts without allowing the knowledge of what came later to inﬂuence our under- standing of this earlier time. It is, of course, controversial to fully consider white ‘slavery’ alongside of Indian and black Atlantic slavery. Guasco and other recent authors who make this case e such as Jenny Shaw, Everyday Life in the Early English Caribbean: Irish, Africans, and the Construction of Difference (Athens, GA 2013) and Simon Newman, A New World of Labor: The Development of Plantation Slavery in the British Atlantic (Philadelphia 2013) e have good reasons for doing so. Nonetheless, there were substantial differences that cannot be ignored. White servants and ‘slaves’ in English colonies were almost always governed by a limited term contract (i.e., not life-long) and their status as servants and slaves was not passed along to their progeny. These things were never (or rarely) true for blacks. Native American enslavement was more wide-ranging, encompassing limited term contracts as well as lifelong, heritable enslavement. And, more to the point (as even Guasco notes), blackness over time became directly associated with slavery, while whiteness took on the opposite connotation. Overall, Guasco's points are well-taken. Slavery was, in fact, far more complicated than we have at times allowed for, and the am- biguities regarding the place and role of Africans, Indians, and other mixed-raced individuals in the opening years of English coloniza- tion is at times hard to parse. Racialized slavery did not simply appear overnight fully formed, among the English or elsewhere. Slavery was completely justiﬁable to the English under certain circumstances (in a just war, for example), but according to Guasco, ‘slavery seems to have offended English sensibilities when it appeared to be ratio- nalized by purely commercial principles’ (p. 73). Review Island on Fire: The Revolt That Ended Slavery in the British Em- pire, . Tom Zoellner. Harvard University Press, Cambridge, MA (2020). 363 pages pp US$29.95 hardcover On December 27, 1831, the largest slave revolt in the British Em- pire began in the plantation lands around Montego Bay in the northwestern corner of Jamaica. Organised through the networks developed by black deacons of the Baptist churches of the region, the uprising occurred in the context of abolitionist pressure to end slavery, following the failure of the ending of the slave trade more than two decades before to bring emancipation any closer. The man who emerged as the revolt's leader, Samuel Sharpe, assured others e as had happened in similar circumstances in Barbados in 1816, and Demerara and Jamaica in 1823 e that he had learned from the newspapers that freedom had been granted by the British king, William IV, but was being withheld from them by the island's white planter elite. In response, the enslaved were encouraged by Sharpe and others not to return to work after the few days allowed at Christmas, but to sit down and refuse to work until they were paid to do so like free men and women should be. They swore oaths that they would stand ﬁrm. Yet if the intention was that this would just be a strike, it did not work out that way. Soon plantation buildings were burning, and black men and women were ﬁghting the militia and the British army with what- ever weapons they could ﬁnd. After ﬁve weeks, when the rebellion was quashed, over ﬁve hundred rebels were dead (compared to only fourteen white people), either killed in battle or via the brutal judicial and extra-judicial retribution that followed. If this revolt failed in securing its immediate aims, it has long been asked what part it e and the planters' bloody response to it e played in the processes that led to passage of the act abolishing slavery in the British Empire through parliament in 1833 and its enactment in 1834. This is the question that Tom Zoellner seeks to answer in what is more a book for a general readership e along the lines of Adam Hochschild's Bury the Chains (2005) e than a work of specialist ac- ademic history. Although his conclusion would seem to be given in the book's title, the interpretation turns out to be more nuanced than that. As he acknowledges early on and explores in the later chapters on the politics of abolition and parliamentary reform in Britain, ‘Sharpe's rebellion did not spur emancipation all by itself, but it certainly hastened the forces that were already in play’ (p. 5). It gave, he argues, the opponents of slavery e by then as likely to be in the Colonial Ofﬁce as in the northern textile factories or the Quaker meetinghouses e ‘the moral and pragmatic ammuni- tion they needed at exactly the right time, with the added force of popular sentiment’ (p. 258). It is e in line with others such as Ver- ene Shepherd, Mary Turner, and Gelien Matthews e who have studied the events of 1831e1832 in Jamaica, and their reverbera- tions in Britain, an afﬁrmation of the part that the resistance of the enslaved played in shaping Jamaican history, British history and the history of empire. As such, it stands as a useful corrective to widespread narratives connecting British imperial morality and the end of slavery. It was a messy business not a foregone conclusion. The book's format and imagined audience means that in setting the context for the events of 1831e1832 it covers a lot of ground that is familiar to students of Caribbean slavery. Zoellner has done due diligence in relation to recent research on the violence of the plantation economy and society, the slave trade, politics and religion in the black diaspora, sugar, and slave resistance. There are some points of emphasis here that might be questioned. For example, in comparison to other studies he rather downplays the cycles of revolts from the late seventeenth century onwards, which serves to make ‘Sam Sharpe's Revolt’ stand out more. Yet it is certainly a matter of debate how far the history of those revolts across the Atlantic world should be understood as a singular, multi-stranded, or disjointed process. In then recounting the events of the revolt in the central chapters of the book, Zoellner offers a detailed narrative animated by particular characters, especially Sharpe, Robert Gardiner, and Thomas Dove, who led the rebels, and Richard Barratt e Elizabeth Barratt Browning's much-disliked cousin e a leading Jamaican politician and planter with an estate near Montego Bay, William ‘Little Breeches’ Grignon, whose militia regiment was forced to ﬂee by the rebels in a battle at Old Montpel- lier plantation, and the Baptist missionaries William Knibb and Thomas Burchell. What Zoellner does particularly well, in these chapters as well as those recounting the political aftermath of the rebellion, is to use the newspaper record to track its reporting in Ja- maica, Britain, and, to a certain extent, the USA. As a result, despite some selective use of archival material in Britain and Jamaica, the study primarily rests on the printed record, both ofﬁcial publica- tions and accounts by white participants such as Henry Belby's Death Struggles of Slavery (1853). Zoellner is, of course, well aware that the nature of the historical sources signiﬁcantly shapes what can be said about the rebels' intentions and political differences e particularly whether the uprising was meant to be a non- violent strike or not e and skews the biographical treatment away from the black participants about whom so much less can be known. Historical Geography at Large Coming to terms with Captain Cook: exhibiting the 250th anniversary of the Endeavour voyage Katherine Parker Hakluyt Society, London On 25 August 1768, the HMB Endeavour sailed from Plymouth, commanded by Lieutenant James Cook. This is the beginning of a familiar tale, the ﬁrst day of the ﬁrst of Cook's three voyages to the Paciﬁc. Lieutenant, and later Captain, James Cook is widely associated with Europe's most comprehensive navigation to that date of the world's largest ocean. He is also noted for the signiﬁcant, and controversial, ﬁrst or early European encounters with peoples and islands includingTahiti, Aotearoa New Zealand, Australia and Hawai'i. 2018 marked 250 years since Endeavour left to observe the Transit of Venus and this latest anniversary offers a chance for more voices to join the ongoing reassessment of Cook's legacy. Three London exhi- bitions in 2018 used the semiquintennial as an opportunity to discuss the Paciﬁc, both as Cook saw it and as it is now.1 They each attempted to offer fresh perspectives on a story which has enduring conse- quences, and the most effective were those that focused less on Cook and his voyages and more on the cultures he encountered. The precise nature of Cook's legacy is a contentious political, cultural and historical issue. For some, Cook remains a heroic martyr to the pursuit of knowledge. For others, Cook is a repre- sentation of national pride. To a growing number, which includes many Paciﬁc Islanders, Cook is an invader whose arrival signalled the onset of damaging settler colonialism.2 Recent vandalism of Cook statues in Gisborne, Aotearoa New Zealand; St. Kilda, Mel- bourne and Hyde Park, Sydney reveal the continuing discontent with how Cook has been commemorated for the past 250 years.3 Scholars have laboured for the previous several decades not so much to enthusiastically vindicate or viciously indict, but to offer nuance to the story and to assign agency beyond the usual (white) protagonists. Although always a popular subject of study, the publication of Cook's journals, edited by J.C. Beaglehole, in 1955, 1961 and 1967 allowed more scholars to access Cook's written words, not just the heavily-mediated published accounts. James Burney (1750e1821) was a veteran of Cook’s second voyage, on which he embarked as able seaman and during which he was commissioned as second lieutenant. On Cook’s third voyage he served as ﬁrst lieutenant to Charles Clerke, captain of the consort vessel Discovery. Henry Roberts (1757e1796), also an able seaman on Cook’s second voyage, proved an apt pupil of the expedition’s ar- tist and was promoted to preparation of the charts and coastal views. On Cook’s third voyage he served as master’s mate aboard the ﬂagship Resolution, where he worked on hydrographic and cartographic tasks with Cook himself and Master William Bligh. Both men kept extensive journals during the third voyage. As the homeward-bound expedition approached Macao at the end of November 1779, the vessel captains collected these and the jour- nals of all other ofﬁcers and crew by order of the Lords of the Admi- ralty. At some point after compilation of the ofﬁcial voyage account, the Burney and Roberts journals were returned to their authors or their heirs. The Mitchell Library of Sydney, Australia, purchased the Burney journal in 1921e22. Collector William Dixson purchased the Roberts journal in 1934 and bequeathed it to the Dixson Library, also in Sydney, in 1952. Both libraries are now part of the State Li- brary of New South Wales, where James Barnett ﬁrst viewed the manuscripts while on a research trip nearly a decade ago. Burney recorded events and impressions in a narrative style that ‘spares much of the tables of courses, winds, and headings, tedious reports that can dominate such journals’ (p. 8). The Roberts journal, on the other hand, was ‘written as a voyage logbook … ﬁlled with the expected chart maker’s daily report of coordinates, as well as hourly tables of courses, winds, and the changing weather’ (p. 13). Barnett has edited out much of the navigation detail while pre- serving the narrative passages, rendering the two journals more comparable. Of course all the familiar major events of the third voyage are covered e dealings with Native inhabitants of various South Paciﬁc islands; ﬁrst sightings of the Hawaiian Islands; Cook’s reverent treatment and subsequent killing at the hands of the Hawaiians; encounters with Native peoples at Nootka and with both Natives and Russians along the southern shores of Alaska; and sightings of the walls of ice north of Bering Strait that dashed all hopes of navigating a Northwest Passage. But there are also many small de- tails that give pause for thought e the shockingly poor condition of the ships’ timbers even at the outset of the voyage; the breeding pairs of European animals introduced as ‘gifts’ to island environ- ments; the spread of venereal disease among island populations; the punishments meted out to Natives for thievery and to crewmen for all manner of infractions; crew members’ revulsion and grief over Cook’s fate; the bone-rattling collisions between fragile ship and immovable ice as the vessels tried to batter a path just a bit farther north. Barnett’s decision to retain as much as possible of the original spelling, capitalization, and punctuation enhances the immediacy of the texts. The book’s overall organization requires a bit of explanation. Barnett presents the voyage in four main parts (the South Seas; the Northwest Passage; Revisiting Hawaiʻi and the Death of Cook; and Homeward), each with an introductory overview. He subdi- vides the parts into voyage segments, each with its own, ﬁner- grained, introduction followed by the two journals’ entries for that segment. The advantage of this approach is to conﬁne most endnotes to the introductions, leaving the journal entries them- selves fairly free of editorial comment. Its principal drawback is a certain amount of repetition, which some readers may ﬁnd annoying. Written as they were by men aboard different vessels and in very different professional roles, the Burney and Roberts journals nicely complement one another. The volume is well illustrated with charts and sketches from both journals and a generous sam- pling of the oft-reproduced watercolors of expedition artist John Webber. Readers already familiar with the voyage will enjoy two fresh narrative perspectives, but no prior expertise is required e ed- itor Barnett provides enough context so that even the uninitiated can appreciate the tale they tell. Mayhew University of Bristol, School of Geographical Sciences, University Road, Bristol, BS8 1SS, UK Abstract This paper attends to the politics and pedagogy of canon formation by looking at the ways in which a century of Anglo-American historiography since the formal consolidation of the discipline in the 1870s has constructed images of geography’s history during the ‘long’ eighteenth century (c.1660e1832). As such, whilst a stable ‘canon’ of geographers such as Cook, Kant and Humboldt has been built, how the individuals who constitute it and their achievements are framed has mutated over time. Keywords: Canonicity; Eighteenth century; History of geography; Historiography The concept of a ‘canon’ has resonances in European thought which are mainly legal-cum-ecclesiastical in historical terms and political in our own age. And yet in fact the term ‘kanonikos’ was ﬁrst coined by Hellenistic grammarians to delineate that set of works which were ‘up to standard’ and therefore worthy of being taught to students.1 Unpacking this, we ﬁnd two sets of issues which this essay will address in the context of the history of geographical thought. First, we have seen intense debates across the humanities and social sciences over the past four decades about the ‘politics of canonicity’. If Hellenistic grammarians wanted to be able to draw a simple binary dividing works up to and below standard, our era has seen a whirlwind of debate, centred in the ﬁeld of literary criticism, about the processes and politics constituting and contesting such evaluative judgements. The very transition from discussion of ‘lit- erary classics’ to debating a ‘canon’ is symptomatic of the turn to critique and contestation of previously taken-for-granted verities about which authors students ought to study.2 To talk of ‘canons’ is almost by deﬁnition to question them, to highlight the economies of evaluation that lie behind them, to raise the possibilities of either a socially-representative canon or of a set of ‘counter canons’.3 And in these ‘canon wars’, there have also been those attempting to defend some notion of a canon as vital to humanities scholarship. Extending and connecting scholarship on critical Mediterraneanism, more-than-wet ontologies and decolonially-inspired geopoetics, this paper addresses the construction of plural and empathic notions of the Mediterranean by Italian cantautore Fabrizio De Andr\x03e (1940–1999). It is worth noting that the Italian term cantautore (quite the equivalent of French chansonnier) has specific nuances in relation to its generic translation, “folksinger.” In fact, although often inspired by popular songs, Italian cantautori are the authors of their texts and often pay tribute to canon- ized poetry in their intentional merging of grassroots and intellectual poetical genres (Eco 2016). The definition cantautori has also specific contexts as it denotates a recognizable movement that characterises Italian music since the second half of the twentieth century. Thus, the term cantau- tore [and its plural cantautori] will be used here in the original Italian. Working with collaborators such as Mauro Pagani, De Andr\x03e engaged with both poetical/ethno- musicological research and radical politics, considering the sea as a place for exchange and cultural conversation rather than a frontier or a space dividing “civilizations.” I especially address texts and contexts of his songs on the Mediterranean, which were the result of sustained reserach on lan- guages and histories of that sea, which exposed how much the language of De Andr\x03e’s city, Genoa, is contaminated by words and sounds coming from the Southern and Eastern shores of the Mediterranean. In Italian scholarship, De Andr\x03e’s geopoetics called the attention of a philosopher committed to the study of Mediterranean (geo)politics and cultures, Franco Cassano (1943–2021). Huang Guozhang (1896e1966), an ambitious young Chinese student with an MA degree in geography from the University of Chicago, returned to Nanjing in 1928 and became an assistant professor in the Department of Geosciences at National Central University. He later became the head of the Department of Geog- raphy at National Beiping Normal University and then the director of the China Institute of Geography. In 1952 the Communist regime accused him of being a tool of imperialism because of his connec- tions with American geography and geographers, stripped him of his title, and relocated him to a remote college in northwest China.
